metadata.title: Science unites a troubled world: Lessons from the pandemic

abstract.text: European Journal of Pharmacology has published a special issue entitled Therapeutic targets and 26 pharmacological treatment of COVID-19 that contains more than 30 manuscripts. Scientists vulnerable of the Lebanese community during the COVID-19 pandemic.

body_text.text: from around the world contributed both review articles and original manuscripts that are 28 remarkable in their diversity. Each contribution offers a unique perspective on the current 29 approaches of the discipline called pharmacology. Yet the contributions share an enthusiasm to 30 put forward a fresh viewpoint and make a positive difference by the exchange of ideas during the 31 troubled times of this pandemic. What other enterprise but science can unite so many diverse 32 cultures and nationalities in global uncertainty and discord, and mobilize an effective response 33 against a common enemy. The efforts of science are in stark contrast to those of populism that 34 has introduced division and a self-serving attitude that are not simply ill-matched to tackle the 35 pandemic, but foster its spread and severity. We trust that the readers of European Journal of 36 Pharmacology will discover new ideas and concepts in our special COVID-19 series as members 37 of the scientific community and shared world. 38 problem from different perspectives. The peer review process is a fundamental 67 pillar of the scientific process, so certainly the growth of preprint publications should be viewed 68 with some concern. Nonetheless, there is strength in dialog and the exchange of ideas. What 69 other enterprise but science can unite so many diverse cultures and nationalities in global 70 uncertainty and discord, and mobilize an effective response against a common enemy. It warms 71 the heart to know that there are still those who believe that knowledge is power. 72

The last several years has seen the growth of populism among many counties in the 73 world, partly as a response to globalization. Unfortunately, a common good is no longer in the 74 national interest; rather, self-interest is now paramount. The alliances and structures that were 75 erected on the hard lessons of the last world war are given short shrift or even cast aside in the 76 name of what is sold as national expediency. It is within that context that the COVID-19 77 pandemic ought to be viewed. 78
